SENT.plain: The Japanese authors first described encephalo-duro-arterio-synangiosis, a new treatment for moya-moya disease, 17 years ago
The other authors used this method (EDAS, indirect anastomosis) in surgical treatment of patients suffered cerebral transient ischaemic attack and cerebral ischaemia
In our department this method was applied in 5 patients with cerebral ischaemia
All patients had internal carotid artery occlusion
After angiography, to localize carotid artery occlusion, acetazolamid (Diamox) test was performed
The patients with negative Diamox test were treated surgically (EDAS)
The authors used the intraoperative microdoppler device to monitor blood flow velocity of the prepared vessel (temporal superficial artery) at every stage of surgery
The device was also useful in controlling the patency of encephalo-duro-arterio-synangiosis percutaneously after the surgery
The proximal and the distal part of the non-bypass anastomosis was examined in the follow up during 5-8 months before angiography
